title: Tuesday, 8th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Morning, then.

BE11:10am

YOU CAN STOP EMAILING ME ABOUT ENQUEST NOW.

GBKrona Jambo
EnQuest PLC (ENQ:LSE): Last: 21.65, up 0.45 (+2.12%), High: 21.95, Low: 21.10, Volume: 1.32m
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:11 am
BE11:11am

(This is Markets Live, BTW. FT Alphaville's thing with etc.)

BE11:11am

So for those who weren't rattling around retail bulletin boards yesterday, here's the story.

Upaswellasdown morning all
BE11:12am

RBC did a 2019 E&P thing yesterday where they rejigged the price deck for Brent at $60ish.

Grouchmonkey Bore Da
RAVER morning
FATDAZ Morning all
Grouchmonkey Kier v frisky this morning.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

As well as stress testing down to $50, where they reckoned Enquest looked offside.

BE11:14am

We upgraded EnQuest in May last year as we believed the stock was undervalued relative to its peers, with the oil price at ~$80/bbl. However with the oil price having retreated to ~$55/bbl, we think there is a risk of a covenant breach if the oil price remains below $60/bbl throughout H1/19. The two upcoming covenant tests (31 March, 30 June) require EnQuest to have an RCF/EBITDA of 1.1x or less, using a training 12-month EBITDA figure. Due to the ongoing Kraken issues this looks increasingly challenging

BE11:14am

Which is wrong.

AC21 SIG's update looks bad
11:14 am
BE11:14am

And has been corrected this morning.

BE11:14am

We published a note earlier incorrectly saying that there was a risk to the company's covenants, which we had wrongly identified to be 1.1x RCF/EBITDA. However, the two upcoming covenant tests (31 March, 30 June) require EnQuest to have a net RCF/EBITDA of 1.5x or less, using a trailing 12-month EBITDA. As demonstrated in exhibit 4, there is no risk of covenant breach under the updated RBC oil price deck.

Natedogg Hi all
BE11:15am

Excel Developer Good FTAV article https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2019/01/07/1546871316000/Odds-of-a-US-recession-are-ticking-higher/
FATDAZ @AC21 yes the headlines sounded v doom and gloom
Natedogg Is there any news on Kier?
nichoman someone won't be winning a broking mandate from enquest!
Alchemy30 morning, ITV and SMDS lively
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Oops. Oh well, no worries. It's stock analysis, not air traffic control.

Blackbag99 Unless you paid for analysis.....
BE11:16am

What's more impressive is that RBC still reaches a 15p target.

FATDAZ On the subject of US recession risk I saw this tweet statisticthis morning which made me sit up https://twitter.com/EconguyRosie/status/1082395141694988289?s=09
BE11:17am

Which has been back engineered like this:

11:17 am
BE11:17am

On a sum-of-the-parts basis, discounting at 12.5% from January 2019, our risked NAV for EnQuest is 47p/share. Our valuation comprises 37p/share for the company’s core asset base (producing fields and firm development projects), including the Scolty Crathes which achieved first oil in November and the Kraken project which came onstream at the end of H1/17. Scotty- Crathes and Kraken remain risked due to production challenges which remain unresolved due to funding constraints, which could impact reserves at year-end. Our price target is set at 15p/share, in line with our Core NAV at $60/bbl long-term. As a development focused business, we expect EnQuest’s stock to reflect its progress in moving developments into production. Our price target in line with our Core NAV reflects implied downside and supports our Underperform recommendation

Manxish Morning everyone
FATDAZ tweet/statistic this morning should say
BE11:18am

Anyway, my email filled up for a lot of yesterday with retail types chucking around all sorts of unhinged stuff.

BE11:19am

Nothing's ever a mistake, everything's always a conspiracy. Anyway, that's that covered. Onwards.

11:19 am
undefined
Excel Developer @Daz: well, expansions are "murdered" by the Fed (Bernanke) and they only do this if they fear the economy is overheating so actually a good year before a recession makes sense to me after a little thought.
red @AC21particularly bad for developed europe it seems...
BE11:20am

On Kier ...........

Kier Group PLC (KIE:LSE): Last: 505.50, up 52.1 (+11.49%), High: 506.80, Low: 447.00, Volume: 643.87k
Flaneur 'lo all - first proper day back today for me!
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Note the Laing O’Rourke refinancing news: https://www.constr...g-deal-with-banks/

PBateman Morning all
FATDAZ @excel I guess so, but the frequency and regularity of it happening surprised me ie we don't learn our lessons from the past.
FATDAZ @red that was what I took away from the headlines
PBateman Nation's favorite contractor/builder/tarmacer , kier
BE11:22am

You've also got a short of 7 per cent or thereabouts to close out now that balance sheet worries have been, if not settled, then at least eased.

PBateman Woodford not taking all of his 409p rights looks silly now
BE11:23am

(@PBateman: could he afford to?)

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Spinning back to an old Numis note from December to outline the case for a rally ......

PBateman @be good call
BE11:24am

We outline here two scenarios for net debt going forward, based on our discussion of key factors with Kier management. Under 'Expected outcome', the group moves to net cash at period end 2019E and nil average monthly net debt by 2021. Under 'Worst case' period end net cash is still attained by 2020 and net average debt falls to net debt:EBITDA of less than 1x by 2021. In both cases, net debt is well within covenants and we therefore conclude that the rights issue raises enough finance, even on the extreme assumption that we argue is very unlikely.

FATDAZ @BE given the SIG news and comments here might it be right to fade these rallies in construction /infrastructure stocks once short covering fizzles out I wonder?
BE11:24am

Focus has been on debt for obvious reasons, but the independent profit forecast of £200m (+/- £20m) is in line with NSe and demonstrates that operationally Kier remains in a strong place, and we also argue that market risk is low given the operational profile.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

They're shop.

BE11:24am

Overall, therefore, we believe the raise will provide the platform to enable ongoing profit growth and a strong balance sheet, so the shares are now – by far – the cheapest in the sector.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

While on construction, SIG and the exciting world of insulation.

RuminationsOn @BE re ENQ - ignore covenants, look at real cf and it all gets horribly tight
SIG PLC (SHI:LSE): Last: 108.50, down 8.1 (-6.95%), High: 113.00, Low: 105.70, Volume: 972.52k
BE11:26am

Mainland Europe's the problem here. Germany and France like-for-likes go south very rapidly in November and December.

Tom Dalgleish @Ruminat, the thimble and pea brigade should be shot
11:27 am
BE11:28am

So FY guide is for £75m, at the bottom of the previous £75-80m range .... though that includes £2-3m of property profits and it's not clear whether that was in the consensus.

BE11:28am

The bigger negative is the net debt line. Guidance goes from 1.5x ebitda to 1.7x.

red @FATDAZin uk there is some pent up demand due to brexit. even in a harder brexit, some will get released, but best felt if get some sort of deal. dev europe however looking ill. even poland where growth was strong, slowed in h2 for sig. so all will be affected.
BE11:29am

Though management still optimistic on 2019, retaining a target for 24% profit growth largely on margin expansion. Ambitious? Maybe.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Well, I was buying Kier big-time at below £4. Had my full-rights. Not pleasant at the time. Thick skin and self-belief needed. Now a v.good start to the New Year!
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Who can we quote here? Peel Hunt's shop so they'll do.

FATDAZ @red thanks for that summary
Blackbag99 Very little macro to support construction going forward @FD. A very mixed bag of price recovery versus no story
BE11:31am

While market conditions are not expected to improve much in 2019, it is difficult to call the scale of potential softness given macro uncertainty. The progress on gross margins is expected to continue (especially as the group walks away from its low margin business) and while the relatively easy overhead savings have been made, the group still thinks there is more to go at in the next 12-18 months. Consensus PBT forecasts for FY19 are £93m and we don't expect that to change much but we are lowering our top of the range estimate by 4% or £4m to £96m. This takes EPS to 12.0p and the current PE to 9.6x. We make a similar reduction to our 2020 estimate. The leverage improvement while good is not quite as good as hoped and will disappoint some but we continue to believe it is being brought under control and the less aggressive year-end working capital management is the right thing to do.

BE11:31am

The shares had a difficult 2018 with them dropping
38%. We continue to believe the business is getting better and that margins will move to a sustainably higher level. Market conditions are proving more of a drag than expected but we remain comfortable with our Buy recommendation given the low ratings.

FATDAZ @Blackbag the wagons do seem to be circling in the retail, commercial and domestic property sectors don't they
11:31 am
undefined
red @FATDAZmkts hate uncertainty. they will take good news obviously, but can also deal with bad. its moving ground that halts business. so to varying degress you'll get a bit of a bounce initially. time line on it depends on what MP's do.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian At the time I don't think Woodford could afford to. Now, I think cash-flows into the fund are positive (start of year) and gives him opportunity to sell down large holdings and take profits in Burford and get to a low average buy-in on Kier. I think this is part reason why Kier SP is doing well ATM.
BE11:32am

ITV had a mention earlier. Mostly, ITV seems to trade as a UK/Brexit proxy these days.

Blackbag99 And i don't see an out anytime soon. I might be anti collapse, but certainly aint bullish
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 132.30, up 6.2 (+4.92%), High: 132.60, Low: 126.25, Volume: 4.02m
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Today, however, we also get STV signing a five-year partnership deal with Sky

FATDAZ @red we are all waiting for Brexit decision in one way or another :(
BE11:33am

STV being the Scottish ITV broadcaster that ITV has, inexplicably, not put in a bid for yet.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Blackbag99 - Buffett never looked for a catalyst in value stocks. If there is an obvious one, you are probably too late into the stock.
BE11:34am

So. STV signs up with Sky for Video on Demand and regional advertising and its shares popped 8% yesterday as a result.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

This opens up the prospect of ITV's retransmission deal with Sky being renewed on same or better terms post the current deal's expiry later this year.

red value/yield uk is looking undervalued if you can see thru brexit. but some folks wont pull trigger till get to otherside.
Blackbag99 @ 1st what do you think Apple will do to Berkshire this quarter. A man who doubled down. I have a feeling Tesco might not be his worst investment ever.
BE11:36am

Here's Liberum.

BE11:36am

Sky’s signing of an agreement with STV suggests (1) Sky is willing to sign a deal and on broadly the same lines as the Virgin deal and (2) Sky appears to be keen to be resolve its outstanding deals sooner rather than later.

In terms of financials, we estimated last year that a Sky-ITV deal would add c. £120m of revenues which is effectively 100% margin, equivalent to a c.15% uplift to consensus medium-term profits. We would feel comfortable with that estimate. To put in context, we have used similar assumptions for a deal with Sky as we used for the ITV-Virgin Media 2018 deal which we estimated would add £35-40m to annualised profits. STV and STV’s commentary at the time of a c. £2m uplift from its Virgin Media deal tied in with our assumptions then (given ITV’s greater scale).

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Thanks BE for the Laing info. I didn't catch that one. ;)
FATDAZ re ITV having been reading about what a fully functioning 5g network will offer in terms of connectivity I think its imperative that ITV pivots more to content sales as income stream because i just can t see traditional advertising or cable / satellite subscription modes surviving that
OLLY I noted RBC upgraded Tullow but down graded Enq using 2 different average oil prices $64 and $60 can you guess the one used for ENQ
11:36 am
BE11:36am

They're buyers of ITV up to 260, so just the 100% upside ....

BE11:37am

Our channel checks suggest national TV advertising for ITV1 has not started too badly for ITV. There is some question how much benefit they are gaining from the dispute between Channel 4 and Publicis (which is c. 10-15% of the UK TV advertising market) but this should be seen as reasonably reassuring given the macro uncertainty. In 2018, ITV’s total advertising (which includes VOD) was +3% in Q1. ITV’s TV advertising performance in January 2018 was -3%.

However, the current share price more than factors in a downturn. If we put a 10% reduction in TV advertising revenues into 2019 forecasts – to put in context, 2009 saw a 8.3% decline – and did not factor in any cost savings then ITV would still be trading at just over 10x adjusted FY19E, suggesting its current de-rating has gone too far.

FATDAZ models not modes
red @Blackbag99apple still spins off a hell of a lot of cash. then theres the bank. it could still buy netflix or tesla in an all cash deal.
undefined
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Blackbag99 - Buffett is shackled by the size of Berkshire. With a fund his size Apple can be seen as attractive. Obviously a big-question mark over Apple becoming a service led business rather than box shifters.
Blackbag99 Apple had £60 Bill in cash last time I looked. It don't buy much
FATDAZ re AAPL I doubt its dead in the water but it will grow a lot slower lets not forget that Nokia was in similar position but without the cash mountain and luxury cache
Viking1 Joules?
chad_john I think traditional TV advertising still has enormous legs to it. Companies are slowly but surely realising that digital advertising is largely snake oil.
red 120-130 now i believe
11:38 am
BE11:39am

While on what we used to call TMT, good note from RBC on Vodafone this morning.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 155.24, down 2.16 (-1.37%), High: 156.56, Low: 154.38, Volume: 21.39m
FATDAZ @chad jon but with Netflix at least for now there are no ads what so ever!
red nokia was hit by a tech switch to smartphones. thats like horses n carts and the car. unless you get a new tech to make smart phones obselete, its not an argument.
BE11:40am

Gist is that 5G's going to cost loads so the divi's toast.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

We believe the market's insouciance over 5G costs materially understates Vodafone's risk. We review recent auctions and technological reasons why 'Mid band is the must Band'. Management regard the Italian auction as artificially high, however the Swedish and Australian results appear to validate it. We believe 5G costs could range from €4.5bn to €12.0bn. Our €8bn mid point would be a negative surprise

DJ Any news Revolution Bars? RBG LN - up 27% in short order..
chad_john @FATDAZ That won't impact brand decisions to spend money on marketing though, or the avenues in which they do so
BE11:40am

Analyst is Wilton Fry, who seems to spend a lot of time writing about spectrum.

BE11:42am

So anyway, you have a €4.1bn divi cost assuming Vodafone holds beyond the March 2019 payout. Which, given the risk of getting junked, looks a bit generous.

Tom Dalgleish @BE if 5G spectrum was bid high in Oz then the stock market hasn't blinked...............yet
Electric Dragon @red no reason nokia couldn't have emulated Sony or Samsung in smartphones: its main mistake was to back a lame horse in the mobile OS/app development race (Symbian)
11:42 am
BE11:43am

We estimate proforma leverage post Liberty at 3.1x net debt / EBITDA despite heavy use of hybrids, mandatory convertibles and deconsolidation of the Netherlands [5.25x] and India [c.24x]. Moody's and S&P both have VOD on a negative stance, indicating a likely downgrade [to BBB from BBB+] post Liberty's closure.

BE11:43am

We believe VOD's 'robust investment grade' policy limits it to BBB and caps leverage at c.3.5x consolidated Net Debt/EBITDA. In our view, Vodafone has insufficient financial headroom given the confluence of headwinds it's facing, namely licence fees, competition, a potential new entrant in Germany [as well as Italy], and the possibility of economic slowdown.

FATDAZ @chad jon it will if the the bulk of the audience consumes the majority of content through Netflix and similar just think about the death of branding in consumer staples as a corollary
Flaneur @red - 5g might go some way to doing that. Smart phones with localised (in the hand) processing power will become irrelevant.Its a continuation/repeat of the hardware to software move that allowed MS to grow in the 1980s when IBM floundered.Your 5g service provider will be the source of all the trickery you need. Manufactured handsets will be of minimal importance - like branded PCs.
Tom Dalgleish @Electric, so youre a non believer in conspiracy theories whenever a critical operating system is sourced outside the US
Viking1 RBG trading update 14/1
Blackbag99 @BE spectrum is hard call. top spectrum which is most of UK clearance is about volume, mid about speed. Top spectrum same business less costs. I pay for speed and volume, don't need anything apple for that :). How it evolves is anyones guess
hornblower @ DJ RBG - Stonegate and Greene King xmas LFLs +12%/11%. snowy last year and xmas day timing helping
BE11:44am

Oh, and proceeds from a (highly likely) minority sale of towers would only fund the divi for one year.

FATDAZ @ electric dragon is IOS that much different by volume of users vs say android or windows ?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Target goes from 260p to 125p. That's that.

undefined
Excel Developer @BE: How can you cut TP by so much?
Flaneur In summary - 5g will move power to the telcos and away from the manufacturers.
red main diff with ios is that it crashes less. if on nonsense like fb its not an issue. but if you cant have apps crashing, its imp
FATDAZ @flanneur and to the consumer which is my point from earlier massive sea changes ahead
BE11:46am

Since on Vod, should note some very negative stuff flying around on Liberty of late.

Tom Dalgleish @Flaneur, so 5G is a pseudo cloud while the handset will simply interpret stuff
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Such as this from JP Morgan.

BE11:46am

Our key concern was that having sold its highest growth assets to Vodafone, the company now faces mounting headwinds across its remaining footprint, leaving its growth profile and premium valuation at risk. We expect 2019 to offer further support for this thesis. Notably, we now anticipate future organic group revenue and OCF growth of just 1% pa, which lowers our EFCF forecasts

10% pa and leads us to trim our Dec-19 TP from $21 to $18. Separately, in-line with the findings of our September 2018 sector report Addicted to debt and dividends, we argue Liberty’s modest growth outlook is insufficient to justify consensus buyback hopes. In fact, even on our $9bn in buybacks (2019-21E) leverage rises to a stretched ~5x by 2022E.

red @Flaneur not sure the likes of vodafone or orange have what it takes to move things on ahead of the likes of smasung and apple
Tom Dalgleish So apps will sit in the cloud and data flow will be keyed to invoke phone features
FATDAZ re 5G wont some of the cost be defrayed by telcos sharing rollout and towers etc
Flaneur @Tom - yes. Exactly.
Viking1 Interesting to see Joules now up 23% since pre Christmas , any comment on trading statement
chad_john Anything on Foot Asylum please BE?
nichoman anything on fdev ?
Flaneur Possibly there'll be 'public phones' or screens and you just pick up and use them as needed - your 'sim card' will plug you into whatever services youve paid for.
BE11:49am

It'd be Liberty style to respond to core pressure by bidding for something, of course.

11:49 am
undefined
red @Flaneurfor that to have any legs, the network needs to be near perfect and data next to free.
FATDAZ @flanneur @Tom Dalgliesh that's why I thought this article / headline was very odd https://www.economist.com/business/2019/01/05/masayoshi-son-wants-arms-blueprints-to-power-all-tech?fsrc=scn/tw/te/bl/ed/masayoshisonwantsarmsblueprintstopoweralltecharmedwithacrystalball
BE11:49am

Over in smallcaps and/or requests .........

red @Flaneurthey already did that during the dotcom days. public booths a non starter imo
Blackbag99 @FD, yes. And the question is in low volume areas, mid band spectrum is probably better than miles of cable. It is till up in the air. If you at the current users, they are looking to offer cheaper volumes. So advances switching on top end spectrum
red of course someone may do it and get paid handsomely for failing with it,
BE11:50am

I can only guess that Frontier Devs is up on the back of Codemasters.

11:50 am
Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 940.00, up 66 (+7.55%), High: 1,000, Low: 874.00, Volume: 67.45k
Codemasters Group Holdings PLC (CDM:LSE): Last: 180.00, up 18.5 (+11.46%), Volume: 64.25k
FATDAZ @Flanneur I understand that physical Sims could be redundant as of now as Sim as Software technology is ready to replace them
Dec69 - Skeptic We should tombstone Foot Asylum, Le Junk du Jour for AIM.
Flaneur @red - indeed. I meant it in the sense that owning a 'phone' might not even be necessary. Services will transfer to any device, instantly. Car, TV, hotel... whatever, wherever.And yes, it'll take time but its already operational in certain Us Telco labs....
BE11:51am

They're as alike as Gucci is to Milletts, but whatever. Codemasters up sharply on news it's developing something with NetEase.

Provender @Flaneur I'm unconvinced. It hasn't happened with PCs despite a lot of hype around VDI over previous years, and they have (effectively) always on networking. I think mobile handsets will become increasingly commoditised, but they will always have significant compute.
Tom Dalgleish So a great collective of telecom companies will have their own iStore emulator
FATDAZ @Blackbag universal coverage wont happen overnight but there will be trickle down quiet quickly I suspect
FATDAZ quite quickly even
Dec69 - Skeptic @FatDaz, the problem with software based sims are many, try a couple of burner apps/phone apps to expand on the issue.
red so what can be agreed upon is that there will be visible earnings growth from the new tech
11:52 am
BE11:53am

You'll remember the argument against Codemasters was that it does B-list racing franchises that sell in shops so don't really have a lot of online engagement and whatever. You'll also remember the argument that that might actually be a positive. Anyway.

FATDAZ @dec 69 thanks for heads up on that
undefined
BE11:53am

FootAsylum. Righty ho.

11:53 am
Footasylum PLC (FOOT:LSE): Last: 26.64, down 5.86 (-18.03%), High: 29.00, Low: 26.64, Volume: 797.41k
Dec69 - Skeptic We looked at this for lowering design costs on phones, didn't get very far as experts disagreed with our thesis. So gave up, albeit didn't go into too much depth.
Tom Dalgleish It's plausible. Telecoms have always wanted a slice of internet profits
Flaneur I'll say one more thing. From what I've seen, the idea is that these recievers/broadcasters/network access devices (lets not call them phones) will be embedded in clothing.... so run with that...
FATDAZ @red there will be a change in business models though whether it will benefits or just those with best coverage execution and content remains to be seen
FATDAZ will benefit everyone sorry
BE11:54am

Who could have predicted on flotation that this completely undifferentiated subscale retailer with total reliance on two or three key suppliers but no leverage over those suppliers wouldn't be a runaway success?

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE how the hell FootAsylum got listed at the price it did is beyond me.
BE11:54am

Everyone? Yep. Everyone. Here's Peel Hunt.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

The Christmas update brings about another lurch down in
consensus as gross margins have been under severe pressure.
Sales growth was in line with hopes but the need to sell through
legacy stock at lower prices has had a material impact and we are
taking another £0.5m off EBITDA numbers that we downgraded
by c20% last week. Management is implementing a cost saving
programme, which makes sense, but it will be a long time, in our
view, before the business generates a profit before tax, and there
is no reason to hold the shares.

FATDAZ @Flanneur I thin thats quite likely how would that suit Apple I wonder ?
BE11:55am

As we read through the statement we were impressed with the early rhetoric. In-store sales growth is 5%, which we think implies LFL very slightly down, which is not a bad effort given how weak footfall has been in general. Online was actually ahead of our H2 estimate with growth of 28%. If we’d stopped reading there, we’d have been reassured.

Dec69 - Skeptic Reminds me of the Bagir listing. Wasn't their main client M&S and their suit sales were falling off a cliff?
BE11:55am

Unfortunately the real news in the statement came on gross margins. It is clear that to generate this satisfactory level of sales growth, management has had to be very aggressive in discounting and promotions. It has been known for a while that Footasylum had an unenviable stock position as a function of some injudicious buying decisions on both
footwear and apparel, and in order to sell this through it is clear that a greater discount has been required than expected. We were forecasting an H2 gross margin that was down by 100 bps but the reality is that it will be down by nearer 300. That obviously leaves quite a dent in gross profit, but on a more positive note, the heavy lifting has now been done on inventory and the stock file is now much cleaner.

Tom Dalgleish Apple and Google will try to corral telecoms early
11:56 am
BE11:56am

We took c20% off our EBITDA numbers last week but it is very difficult to hold even our new numbers on the basis of such a troubled gross margin. Management is suggesting that it is beginning a cost saving programme: that is going to have to click into place very quickly if our new
number is going to be delivered, and we don’t actually sense that Footasylum was a “fat” business in the first place: we fear that taking cost out could impact customer service standards and reduce the amount that is available for marketing. That’s not a spiral management will want to get on, and the trick here is going to be to generate some underlying LFL sales growth without recourse to lower gross margins. That won’t be easy, given the competitive landscape and the probability that news like today’s doesn’t help relationships with the big suppliers. We are taking £0.5m off our outer year numbers, but over time we will need more chapter and verse on strategic direction.

BE11:57am

(@Dec69: M&S pulled the contract a few months after Bagir floated, if I remember correctly. Total scenes.)

Blackbag99 @FD 2028 TV spectrum licences end. There isn't a timetable for renewal currently. But it is all mid spectrum speed delivery. ATM UKGOV pays subsidy to spectrum to TV cos. If TV goes from the spectrum, all bets are off
FATDAZ by all thanks for today
BE11:57am

That's Jonathan Pritchard, who says to switch into JD.

11:57 am
JD Sports Fashion PLC (JD.:LSE): Last: 379.70, up 4.7 (+1.25%), High: 381.10, Low: 370.50, Volume: 2.67m
chad_john Thanks for FOOT, BE
red @FATDAZappl does a lot of servs rev, just although massive, still dwarfed by iphone sales. about a quart i believe.
undefined
Dec69 - Skeptic Of interest are the amount of InstaGram adverts flying around at the moment. I'm finding Facebook and social media/communications apps are in down trend. Novelties of Fox ears on my goat face have worn off significantly.
BE11:59am

Oh, and bog roll.

11:59 am
Accrol Group Holdings PLC (ACRL:LSE): Last: 12.18, down 8.82 (-42.02%), High: 12.60, Low: 12.60, Volume: 3.99m
red @Dec69 - Skeptici think they are pinning hopes on whatsapp pay and also bringing ads there.
BE11:59am

Profit warning. Again. Sterling and input cost inflation.

Tom Dalgleish Rings true that nobody wants Huawei at the hub of 5G if every connected device is a slave
Dec69 - Skeptic @Red, Whatsapp for business appears to be working for customer support and is an expense saver to business who can near deal with issues instantly. Assuming staffed correctly. The adverts are interesting, as whilst travelling I get adverts for the UK whilst no longer resident there, how many retailers are paying for these alleged targeted campaigns where the intended doesn't even have an interest in that jurisdiction etc...
Blackbag99 Accrol, brexit profit warning wears thin. In a market where wearing thin leaves nasty stains.
Blank canvas thanks for everything today BE and fellow rubble on the right
Excel Developer Re Brexit: the eurosceptic press have not been challenged for decades, something that was pleasingly raised in last night channel 4 drama
BE12:03pm

It's had a troubled past, has Accrol. Shortly after floating it took a big fine when a person at its Blackburn factory lost a finger.

cracklenpop re. Arrol - Zeus is the house broker.
Shinshin @Dec Usual monetisation dilemma though. One of the key attractions of Whatsapp is no ads. But if they intro ads it's an easy switch to Signal / Telegram / Wechat etc

Investment view: Clearly macro headwinds have continued to impact near term trading and have proven to be a persistent challenge for the group. While this is a disappointing update we believe the group has made good progress with the restructuring programme which should benefit profits as cost savings annualise over the next financial year. We believe Accrol remains well positioned to benefit from the continued growth of discount retailers and has significant opportunity across the wider retail segment. In our view this continues to carry long term strategic value that should be unlocked as its recovery builds momentum post 2019.

BE12:08pm

Joules has traded impressively over Christmas with total retail sales up
+11.7% over the seven weeks to 6th January 2019. This is an acceleration
from the +10% delivered in H1, extending the group's track record of
consistent outperformance vs. peers in a tough market. E-commerce
accounted for 50% of revenue, reflecting the strength of the group's online offer, balanced growth model and favourable positioning in light of the market’s structural shifts. Our forecasts are unchanged but even more
secure following this performance over peak. We expect continued doubledigit top line momentum over the long-term to be complemented by the capture of operational leverage from the group's well-invested infrastructure. Reiterate BUY and TP of 420p.

BE12:09pm

Following the sectors de-valuation and deterioration in the outlook on many retail firms across the sector, we believe the share price fall in Joules is unwarranted. Joules now trades on an FY2 EV/Sales of 0.9x, an EV/EBITDA of 7.6x, an 11% discount to the wider sector that includes the likes of Debenhams and Superdry who drag the average down. Joules currently trades on an May 2020 (FY2) PE of 15.0x, a 20% discount to the clothing & apparel average, which we do not think is fair value, considering both today’s excellent update, and an H1 trading update (which included November) that was ahead of market expectations.
